posts.cooked: We will calibrate our thrifty cams, but before doing so, we wanted to know if there are any good tricks or tips anyone might know that could help improve calibration accuracy. We were also interested in hearing from those who use thrifty cams what their current settings (resolution, decimation, etc.) are set to. Additionally, we’d appreciate advice on how much to adjust the thrifty cams to achieve the desired focus.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I don’t have a ThriftyCam, so I’m not sure about your question. Focus can usually be achieved by placing the camera pointed at an object and adjusting the lens-to-sensor distance until the object appears sharpest, often by slightly turning the lens in the camera’s mount. Using something like an AprilTag or large, clear text on a wall at a couple of meters can work well as a target.  

For precise focus, tools like Limelight offer numeric measurements. I created a program using a Siemens Star pattern along with it, though I’m not fully familiar with their specific algorithm. While the research and coding were fun, I found the simple eyeball method to be quicker and just as effective. Here’s a quick Java snippet from a calibration script that uses Laplace operators for edge detection:

```java
Imgproc.Laplacian(gray, lap, 3); // Detects edges in the image
Core.meanStdDev(lap, mean, standardDeviation); // Calculates the variance across the image
```

This method effectively isolates high-frequency details, making it easier to manually adjust focus.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
What calibration results did you get? Using an online-purchased ChArUco board, we achieved approximately 0.5 pixel reprojection error. Our setup involved positioning ourselves two feet away from the board and capturing over 50 images in various orientations to fully cover the calibration window with the colored markers.

For focus, the process involves adjusting the lens until the target comes into sharp focus or aligns with the desired tracking performance.

Calibration settings are dependent on the specific coprocessor used, as different devices may require unique decimation and resolution configurations. While I am expecting to receive an OrangePi soon, providing more generalized data, the current settings we use are not commonly applicable across different hardware setups.

To adjust the focus of budget-friendly cameras, manual lens distance adjustment to the sensor is necessary. I was curious what settings work well for capturing both distant and close subjects (2 meters being effective). Would you suggest applying adhesive tape or glue along the lens edge to keep it stable?

We have not yet calibrated the cameras, and I can provide that information tomorrow when we do. Would you recommend buying a ChArUco board or printing one that uses PV? Would you recommend using PV calibration? Lastly, doesn’t Apriltags’ distances change over the course of a match, so did you guys have to find a sharpness setting that worked for both far and close tags?

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
Sharpness setup for a distance within 4-6 feet worked well enough to also see tags that were much further away. Focus with such a small lens does not require that much of a headache. I would not use a printed one. I would either buy one or use a iPad/tablet screen and measure the square size with calipers. Looking for a reliable and affordable way to calibrate your cameras for 2025? I’m excited to share a new product: Charuco Calibration Targets, designed specifically for teams looking to achieve professional-quality camera calibration without breaking the bank. Why These Targets?

Flat and Durable: Made from 6mm aluminum composite, these targets stay flat, ensuring consistent and accurate calibration results. Cost-Effective: Comparable to professional-grade targets but at a fraction of the price…
We will definitely use your idea. The resolution you choose won't affect the charuco board.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: You need to calibrate your camera at the resolution you plan to use for tracking. This resolution will provide the best frame rate and latency. The camera’s performance remains consistent regardless of the resolution chosen.
Thank you for your assistance; that makes sense.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: There is some doubt about how much pose accuracy you can get with distant AprilTags (using a larger standard deviation). If you are determined to extract the last bit of performance from them, consider using this focus strategy: While viewing the 3D pose wireframe displayed on the AprilTag at the maximum distance you want to use, adjust the focus until the wireframe appears and disappears. Mark the midpoint between the most clockwise and counterclockwise positions where the wireframe is visible. This is likely the optimal position for accurate interpretation. Up-close tags may appear slightly blurry, but the initial vision processing step in detecting tags already applies a blur function. Additionally, verify that different tags can be detected and interpreted across various distances. If the lens isn’t securely held in place, a small dot of hot glue may be necessary. Although we haven’t personally tested this, we didn’t accompany the team to the competition and didn’t inspect the focus adjustments during the recent trip, so we’re unsure how much the robot and camera were affected en route.
Okay, thank you for the help. I will try this tomorrow during Robotics.

Could you check these camera calibrations please? The files attached below include the calibration settings for the Thrifty Cam 55-degree lens.  

- **PhotonCalibrationFrontLeft.json** (187.3 KB)  
- **PhotonCalibrationBackRight.json** (413.1 KB)  
- **PhotonCalibrationBackLeft.json** (342.5 KB)  
- **PhotonCalibrationFrontRight.json** (379.8 KB)

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Arguably, back left is the outlier. I would calibrate it two or three more times and see what I get.
Okay, I will do that. Thanks.
